description:
Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus HD100 is a predatory bacterium that belongs to the Deltaproteobacteria class. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and motile microorganism that exhibits a unique life cycle involving the invasion and consumption of other bacteria, particularly Gram-negative species.

The distinctive feature of B. bacteriovorus HD100 is its ability to prey on a wide range of bacterial hosts, including pathogens such as Escherichia coli, Salmonella, and Pseudomonas. Upon encountering a suitable host, B. bacteriovorus attaches to the outer membrane of the prey cell and penetrates its periplasmic space, where it then multiplies and consumes the host's cellular contents. This process ultimately leads to the lysis and destruction of the host bacterium, releasing the B. bacteriovorus progeny to seek and infect new prey.

The genome of B. bacteriovorus HD100 has been sequenced, revealing insights into its predatory mechanisms and adaptations. This species is considered a potential biocontrol agent and has garnered interest in various applications, such as the development of alternative antibacterial strategies and the study of interspecies interactions within microbial communities.
